Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Multifunctional Nanocomposites with Reversible Switch and Controlled Release Surfaces

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objective and Approach
This research is a fundamental study on surface switching and self-cleaning/release mechanisms and the development of new design concepts for manufacturing nanocomposite-based switchable surfaces. In this project, new multifunctional nanomaterials with surface switching, self-cleaning and controlled release on demand will be created. The nanocomposite materials and the associated surface dynamic behavior will be characterized quantitatively at the nanoscale. In addition, a multiscale modeling at atomistic and micromechanics scales is proposed to interpret experimental results and to address how the physical, chemical and structural properties of nanomaterials can be translated into enhanced switching performance. The modeling and experiment will be integrated to link the nanoscale phenomena to macroscopic performance.

Benefits to society
If successful, the benefits of this research will include a fundamental understanding of switching mechanisms for the design and development of optimized materials with better performance of practical significance. The success of the project will also advance a large variety of other applications, ranging from simple consumer products to complex technological systems with surface switching and self-cleaning/release properties. This collaborative research effort will impact the scientific and industrial communities to understand an array of materials and surface technologies. The major research outcome of this project is a technical platform for the development of next generation switchable surfaces. Furthermore, both undergraduate and graduate students will be trained in emerging and interdisciplinary research. Research and education efforts will be disseminated through conference presentations and scholarly publications that will be beneficial to the scientific community and our society.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, stimuli-responsive composite films were prepared and tested under controlled humidity and electric field. These composites are not only sensitive to humidity but also to electric signals. In addition, flexible and wearable wire-shaped microsupercapacitors (Image 1)were prepared for regeneration of optic nerve via electrical stimulation, and surface fluorescent carbon dots from milk by microwave cooking. A unique self-cleaning mechanism of the nano-pads of gecko feet was found. By mimicking the natural design of gecko feet, biomimetic micromanipulators (Image 2) were fabricated, which show similar effects, and this approach provides a new way to manipulate microparticles in dry and aqueous environments.  In addition to the experimental work, modeling of the materials and devices were also carried out to explain the phenomena found in the experiments. The theoretical work includes modeling of dynamic effects of gecko setae and particles, mechanical behavior of carbon nanotube-graphene nanostructures, and covalent organic frameworks as efficient electrocatalysts in clean energy conversion and green oxidizer production.

Intellectual Merits: We have developed a series of wire-shaped microsupercapacitors that are so flexible that they can be bent over a large angle and woven into a textile. Furthermore, the output current and voltage of these wire-shaped microsupercapacitors can be easily tuned by connecting them in series or in parallel. The electric-field induced transitions are highly reversible and reproducible, indicating the achievement of a stable response of the composite films to electric-field stimuli. These wearable wire-shaped electronics for energy conversion and/or storage have great potentials for various applications, especially as integrated electronics with clothing and other textiles. Apart from the potential use as electronics with clothing and other textiles, the microsupercapacitors developed in this project can also provide electrical energy for other electronics, including on-body sensors.

This study has provided direct evidence that the unique shape of nanoscale spatula pads plays a crucial role in generating robust and stable adhesion while permitting efficient self-cleaning capabilities in dynamic regimes. Furthermore, emulating the gecko self-cleaning principle has led to the design of novel artificial setae as powerful micromanipulation tools, which can viably manipulate and precisely assemble micro-/nano-particles by simply tuning pull-off velocity. It is foreseeable that this self-cleaning mechanism has important impacts on the design and development of many biologically inspired technologies, including smart and antifouling surfaces, micro-/nano assemblies, underwater cell manipulation technologies, and MEMS devices. The modeling developed in this project has gained a fundamental understanding of the phenomena found in the experiments.

Broader Impacts: This work should open the door to the development of novel highly-efficient biomimetic self-cleaning adhesives, wearable devices, smart surfaces, MEMS, tunable micro/nano-manipulators, biomedical devices, and more. The materials and devices studied in this project are unique and could be commercialized for many applications such as sensors, electrocatalysts drug delivery or electric probes, detection and therapy of tumors. The pH-controllable antitumor drugs might open up possibilities for the design of novel nanostructured oral drugs for various applications, such as detection and therapy of tumors.

The participating students at all levels were exposed to nanoscience and nanotechnology. Supported by the NSF grant, four graduate students have directly been involved in this research.  Student(s) from under-represented groups were encouraged to participate in the research. Four female undergraduates have actively participated in the project during the summers. Six high school students have been involved in the research in PI’s labs. These students have won several scholarships due to their innovative research, and all of them have selected engineering as their college major. In addition, the students’ parents have expressed more interest in our work through the visit of our university and our labs. One book and two book chapters have been published, and 32 papers have been published in top scientific journals. The related work has been presented in national and international conferences.
